title: leaders call uk heal divided society
story: The representatives of some of the country’s biggest organisations want a “decade of reconnection” after years of bitter Brexit rows.In an open letter, they observe “our country feels more fragmented than any of us would like” and say it falls to all of us to do something about it.The leaders say we should start by reaching out to one person we do not know or from whom we have drted apart.Their letter adds: “While our politics and media have become more polarised we, as people, have not. There is much that we share with each other.”The clarion call has been backed by Sir Hugh Robertson, of the British Olympic Association, Glastonbury festival boss Emily Eavis, Dame Carolyn Fairbairn from the CBI and Matt Hyde, of The Scout Association.The letter has also been signed by the Young Vic theatre’s artistic director Kwame Kwei­Armah, Mike Sharrock of the British Paralympic Association — and the former heads of the Leave and Remain campaigns, Matthew Elliott and Will Straw.Church leaders, union bosses and charities also joined the call for unity.It comes as surveys have shown more than two thirds of the population are angrier about politics and society than before the referendum.A fth admit they often or always feel lonely despite eight in ten saying people from dferent backgrounds get on well.The leaders’ letter calls on Brits to “reach out to just one person we don’t know, or from whom we have drted apart”.It adds: “Every institution, too — not just government but education, business, sport, civic society and faith — should play its part in helping bridge social ides.“Today is about a small first step that we can all take — to leave behind ision and begin our decade of reconnection.”Imam Qari Asim, chair of the Mosques and Imams National Advisory Board, warned that growing apart breeds fear of those who we do not know or appear dferent.He said: “The start of a new decade offers us a moment of change and of hope — that we can all reach out and find a connection with someone new.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pope francis lashes worshipper arm st peters square
story: The -year-old was on his way to visit a nativity scene in Vatican Citys central plaza when the woman grabbed his hand and yanked him towards her.He had reached over a barrier to touch a child and had already turned to walk away when he was pulled back.The visibly-shocked pontf stumbled slightly as he moved back towards the barrier and appeared to be in some pain.He then scolded the woman verbally before slapping her hand twice when she still refused to let go.Security guards then moved in to pry the woman off him.The woman had made the sign of the cross as the Pope walked towards her, and was trying to talk to him as she held his hand, although it is not clear what she was saying.The Pope has now apologised over the incident.He was later filmed continuing to shake hands with worshippers and kissing the cheek of a baby passed to his guards by its mother.At the New Years Eve evening service at St Peters Basilica, the Pope told the congregation to practice solidarity and to build bridges, not walls.On Christmas Eve, he said the light of Christmas should be allowed to counter the darkness of human hearts, mentioning in particular unrest in Ukraine, Venezuela, Syria, and a number of countries in Africa.He also called for compassion for migrants forced by conflicts and economic hardship to emigrate in the hope of a secure le.He said that after perilous journeys, they are often find themselves before walls of indference in places where they might have hoped for a dignied le.The New Years incident is not the first time the Pope has rebuffed affection by the faithful.In March, he was filmed repeatedly pulling away his hand as followers made to kiss his ring during a visit to Italys Holy House of Loreto basilica.Vatican spokesman Alessandro Gisotti later explained the footage, saying: The Holy Father told me that the motivation was very simple: hygiene.He wants to avoid the risk of contagion for the people, not for him.

title: uk new years eve celebration style party
story: Thousands of partygoers donned bright and tight outfits as they hit the bars and clubs across the UK to mark the arrival of  last night.Revellers dressed in roaring s style to mark the new s decade while others slapped on bright wigs and dresses for the new year.Many gallant lads were pictured helping out female friends - giving them piggy backs as respite from their towering heels.From Leeds to Blackpool, groups of friends were pictured going into the new decade with a bang as firework shows were sent spinning into the sky across the cities.But as the night wore on, some smiles slid slightly as pals helped each other limp home after the raucous night.However, it wasnt all fun and games as the night descended into chaos for some Brits.Some were pictured being taken away by cops as the night got out of hand - including in Leeds.In London,  people were arrested as police patrolled the capitals celebrations.Among those taken into custody by cops by am, three people were arrested for being drunk and disorderly, while another was arrested for possession of a lock kne.Another two were arrested for possession of drugs and one on affray.They have since been taken to central London police stations.Meanwhile, officers were rushed to a South East Home just after midnight on reports of a fight at a house party.Three teen boys were found with stab injuries at the Casewick Road home.Their condition is not believed to be le-threatening.Three people were arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and taken to a south London police station where they remain in custody.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBetween Brexit, the election and a new prime minister, itaposs been a long and confusing year in politics. Rules, benefit systems - even the date weaposre going to leave the EU - have been repeatedly chopped and changed. And many of the changes made to our laws and budgets donapost take effect immediately. Most will involve some lead time before the changes come into force - so itaposs easy to forget whataposs coming up. So weaposve rounded up  of the major changes to UK law, benefits, financial and employment rules that are set to take place in . They include increases to the minimum wage, new rights for gig economy workers and changes to the laws on gay marriage and abortion in Northern Ireland. Read on to see how theyaposll affect you and your family. January : Rail fares rise by .% Rail fares are to jump by an average of .% as the latest inflation-linked hike kicks in. Some long-distance commuters will see the annual cost of getting to work increase by more than £ on  January. It means a £, season ticket will rise by £., while a London to Guildford annual ticket, which typically costs £, will rise by £ to £,. January : Gay marriage is legalised in Northern Ireland Northern Irelandaposs ban on same-sex marriage will officially come to an end, after Westminster politicians stepped in and changed the law. Although the weddings will be legal from this date, bureaucracy means the first civil same-sex marriages are expected to take place on the week of Valentineaposs Day. March : Alcohol minimum pricing launches in Wales The Welsh Government is planning on a new law setting minimum alcohol prices, WalesOnline reports. Currently set to come into force on March , , ministers want retailers and bars to charge a minimum of p per unit - meaning a can of cider could cost at least £ and a bottle of wine, £.. Health minister Vaughan Gething confirmed the start date in a statement to Assembly members in October. However, the regulations which will set out the timetable and minimum prices, still need to be approved by the Welsh Assembly. The policy has already been delayed from last summer. March : The right to request decent affordable broadband Hundreds of thousands of homes and businesses have the choice of slow broadband, hideously expensive broadband, or no broadband. Thataposs set to end for many with a new right called the Universal Service Obligation. From March , anyone can request a connection that can deliver  megabits per seconddownload speed and  Mbps upload speed and costs less than £ per month. If you donapost have internet of this quality, you have the legal right to request it, as long as the installation would cost less than £,. If it costs more, you can still have broadband installed but may have to pay the excess cost. The scheme is being administered by BT and KCOM in Hull. Once a request is made, there are set standards for how quickly they must assess and deliver on requests. March : Abortion is made legal in Northern Ireland From the end of March, women in Northern Ireland will be allowed to terminate pregnancies without fear of prosecution. That means the region will be brought in line with the rest of the UK by the beginning of April. The change was approved by the UK Parliament as part of the Northern IrelandBill - introducing the law in the absence of the collapsed devolved government. From April, abortion services will be available from two hospitals. Buffer zones will be in place to prevent protests outside the centres. Itaposs thought around , will take place each year in Northern Ireland. April : Councils can double council tax for empty homes  Property owners can already face Council Tax bills increasing by %they leave properties vacant for more than two years. And from April, that figure increases to % - potentially doubling the charge for homes left empty for long periods of time.  April : Hospital parking charges axed - for some Hospital parking charges for thousands of NHS patients and staff will be scrapped in England from April . Blue badge holders, frequent outpatients and parents of sick kids are among the groups that will benefit from the Tory pledge - which comes after a long Mirror campaign. But not all NHS staff and patients will get free parking, as they would have done under Labouraposs plans. Instead of being scrapped altogether, the £m-a-year paid to park at NHS hospitals will be scaled back by just under a third, saving patients and staff up to £m a year. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said it would prioritise those with the greatest need adding: One of the concerns mentioned regularly on the doorsteps was that vulnerable people, and staff working nights, have to pay for hospital car parking. So we are today delivering on our manesto commitment and setting out our new approach to NHS hospital parking charges.  Weaposre currently expecting a new rate of £. for those aged  and over, up from £. an hour now, but the exact figure canapost be confirmed yet. New hourly rates for the following April are announced in the Budget, which we are only expecting in February due to delays around the election. April : Changes to rights for agency and gig economy workers Currently, when people who earn ying amounts of money from week-to-week - particularly those on flexible contracts - take a paid holiday, the employer has to pay them holiday pay which equates to the average weekly wage they earned over the  weeks before that holiday. From April , , that is changing. Employers will have to calculate the average weekly wage from an entire year -  weeks - rather than just  weeks. The reform is intended to improve the holiday pay for seasonal workers, who tend to lose out over the way it is currently calculated. Written statement Employers will also be required to provide a aposstatement of particularsapos on day one of employment - which must include:Hours and days of the week the worker employee is required to work, whether they may be ied and how Entitlements to paid leave Details of any probationary period Details of training provided by the employerParental bereavement leave Way back in , the Government backed a Private Members bill which proposed giving workers the right to unpaid leave of up to two weeks, as a right, from day one of their employment, should they suffer the tragedy of their child dying under the age of . This became law in September, , and is expected to come into force in early . While most employers do give discretionary compassionate leave in such tragic circumstances, some do not. This law, which also applies to women who suffer a stillbirth or miscarriage from the th week of pregnancy, changes that. April : National Insurance is cut by up to £ a year The Tories pledged to raise national insurance thresholds in their manesto. From April, you will pay no national insurance contributions on the first £, of your earnings - up from £, at the moment - working out as a saving of around £ a year.The move has been criticised for falling short of the £-a-year Boris Johnson promised, and only helping better earners who are already over the threshold.For others itaposs not quite the all out win you might think - with the move meaning some of the worst off might now miss out on some of their state pension as a result. Steven Cameron, pensions director at Aegon, said: “Under current rules, those not paying any NI lose out on credits towards their state pension. Iniduals need  years of qualying NICs to receive the full state pension with those with fewer qualying years seeing a reduction and receive nonethey have fewer than  years of credits.” April : Tories will let families inherit £million tax free - finishing what George Osborne started Families will be able to pass £m of their wealth without Inheritance Tax when they die. Currently someone who dies can leave £, of their estate tax-free. But Tory George Osborne added an extra extra tax-free amount that applies only to property. In April this extra portion rises from £, to £, - meaningsomeone owns a home, they can leave £, tax free. This doublesa couple is married. April : Student loan repayments will fall  People paying back student loans get a minor tax break in April too. Recent graduates will be able to earn £, a year before payments kick in - up from £, this year. That should save them £. in payments a year. People who graduated between  and  will see their threshold rise too - from £, a year to £,. April : State pension will rise by .% The state pension will rise by .% from April - more than double the rate of inflation. Such an increase means pensioners can expect an rise of just over £ per week on the New State Pension from the current rate of £.. But hundreds of thousands of over-s will see around half their pension rise wiped out by the cost of paying for their own TV licence, after the benefit was scrapped. Tory ministers pledged to protect the state pension with a apostriple lockapos. That means it rises by inflation, .% or average earnings - whichever is highest. Average weekly earnings rose by .% in the year to May to July . April : Benefit freeze ends After almost a decade of freezes and caps, about . million people on Universal Credit and millions more on legacy benefits will get a .% increase in April. The increase means someone on £ a month in benefits will get an extra £.. But it is less than the rise in average earnings and less than the rise in pensions. April: Council tax to rise Local authorities will get the power to raise council tax by up to % from April - % for general spending and % for social care. Thataposs worth an extra £ to on the average band D council tax home in England. Council-by-council rises will only be confirmed in February and March. title: 9 fascinating bits secret history
story: News fascinating bits of secret history revealed in New Year declassied documentsDetails of some of the most important historical moments of the s and s have been released by the National Archives under the  year rule - revealing fascinating insights into Margaret Thatcher, John Major and other key figuresShareCommentsByBrian HuttonMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentBen GlazeNicola Bartlett:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsPrime Minister Margaret Thatcher " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMargaret Thatcheraposs fury over Northern Ireland troop deaths, John Majoraposs all encompassing love of cricket and MPs fears over unflattering camera angles. These are just some of the fascinating details revealed this week in official documents from the s and aposs, newly declassied by National Archives in Dublin and London. The files were released under the  year rule -  years in Ireland - which requires secret documents to be declassied after two decades unless there is a good reason not to. UK documents are revealed by the National Archives at Kew unless they would cause damage to the countryaposs image, national security or foreign relations. In the UK, documents are released twice a year in August and January - but theyaposre still playing catch-up with declassications, after the time limit was reduced from  years to  in . Hereaposs a round-up of the most interesting stories that emerged in this yearaposs releases. . Nuclear weapons could be hidden inside a Northern Ireland mountain  Nuclear weapons could be sited at underground facilities inside a mountain in Northern Ireland, Dublin’s most senior intelligence official advised the government. Colonel L Buckley, then Ireland’s Director of Intelligence, was asked for a briefing for Irish Minister of Foreign Affairs Peter Barry on the possibility of nuclear missiles being on the island in November . In a response marked “Confidential”, Buckley complains that he doesn’t have “the monitoring or surveillance systems” to confirm the movements of UK ships, aircraft and support systems. “Suffice to say any such information would be given the highest security classication and only be available to UK or or other military personnel on the strictest ‘need-to-know’ basis at the highest level,” he added.  But he said the harbour at Sydenham in Belfast could accommodate Royal Navy or Nato ships “equipped with nuclear missiles or weapons”. And he said a military base at Benbradagh Mountain,overlooking Dungiven in Co Derry, the second highest mountain in the Sperrins which was used by US forces during the Cold War to communicate with its north Atlantic fleet, could hold nuclear weapons. “Ben Bradaigh NEof Dungiven has underground facilities, which were originally constructed by US forces for the storage of conventional high explosives but were subsequently redesigned and are understood to be suitable for the storage of nuclear weaponsso required,” he wrote.  Margaret Thatcher “grabbed her handbag” and “stormed out” of a meeting with the Belgian prime minister in a row over the extradition of an Irish priest wanted in London over alleged connections to the IRA A senior Tory adviser told an Irish diplomat about the incident by way of contrasting Thatcher’s “quite natural” way with then Irish Taoiseach Charlie Haughey, adding there was “a lot to be played for between them”.  . Thatcher kept wrongly convicted Birmingham Six in jail to dodge scandal The Thatcher government was reluctant to free the Birmingham Six because of pressure from Tory hardliners and concerns it would cause a “scandal”. A Home Office official admitted the fears to Irish diplomats  years ago. The Irish government was leaned on not to pursue their case with the European Court of Human Rights. PM Margaret Thatcher’s government also feared a backlash from the media. Paddy Hill, Gerry Hunter, Johnny Walker, Hugh ­Callaghan, Richard McIlkenny and Billy Power were freed in  for one of the worst miscarriages of justice after being ly convicted in  for the Birmingham pub bombings that killed  people in November .  . Thatcheraposs fury over aposher boysapos killed in Northern Ireland Margaret Thatcher had warned Northern Ireland’s police chief that she would no longer send “her boys over in waves to be killed” in a rancorous row over who was to blame for the slaughter of eight soldiers in an IRA bomb. Sir John Hermon, then chief constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, was upset by the “neo-colonial connotations” and “World War I overtones” of the Prime Minister’s dressing down, which he took as distancing of herself from the region, newly declassied files disclose. The IRA detonated a massive roadside bomb, containing  pounds of semtex, as an unmarked bus carrying members from the Light Infantry made its way along the A at Ballygawley, Co Tyrone, after midnight on August , . Eight soldiers - all aged between  and  - were killed and another  were injured. They had been making their way from the airport to their base at Omagh. Six months later, Sir John confided in a diplomat about the “panic reaction” from Downing Street in the wake of the attack as well as tensions between the police and the army over whose fault it was for the deadly security lapse.  . Tory who avoided aposblacks and Irishapos feared for apossecurity implicationsapos of allowing Irish MPAn aposunsavouryapos Tory MP who openly admitted avoiding the blacks and Irish in his constituency feared the security implications of allowing Irish politicians into Westminster .Nicholas Budgen, who took over Enoch Powell’s House of Commons seat for Wolverhampton South West, agreed to have lunch with Richard Ryan, a diplomat in the Irish Embassy in London, in March , a report of the meeting marked “confidential” shows. Ryan was trying to bolster support - and stymie opposition - to the nascent British-Irish Inter-Parliamentary Body, made up of politicians in London and Dublin. . Officials feared John Major would have to aposhide behind plantapos as Bill Clinton visited UK  Officials feared the Prime Minister would be forced to hide behind a pot plant to avoid shaking a Sinn Fein leaderaposs hand. Aides were worried about a chance meeting between PM John Major and Sinn Feinaposs Gerry Adams during US President Bill Clintonaposs trip to the UK. The American President visited London and Belfast in November . Stormont aide Robert Crawford issued the alert for potential embarrassment in a memo to Mr Majoraposs private secretary, Edward Oakden. Mr Crawford wrote: Sinn Feinwill almost certainly be invited to the reception. “We cannot see a way of the Prime Minister avoiding Gerry Adams without reverting to the undignied hiding-behind-the-potted plants scenario, which creates almost as valuable a news story as the first handshake.  Ministers were accused of “manipulating” the grieving Dunblane community in the aftermath of the massacre of  children and their teacher. Parents of youngsters gunned down by murderer Thomas Hamilton demanded an urgent clarication from Prime Minister John Major days after the  tragedy, amid fears the Government was about to U-turn on a pledge to help, a newly-released letter reveals. Relatives were angered by reports Scottish Minister Michael Forsyth was abandoning a pledge to offer taxpayersapos money to rebuild the gym where Hamilton slaughtered five and six-year-olds. The PM and Mr Forsyth were among a delegation to visit the Scottish town after the March  attack. Mr Major confirmed to the headteacher that finding Government cash for the project would not be a problem. Gerry McDermott, spokesman for the school board of governors, said the gesture was a source of great comfort to the community, relieving strain from those most closely involved.  John Major skipped seeing Britainaposs only gold medal of the  Olympics because he wanted to watch cricket instead, official records suggest. Aides to the then Prime Minister tried to persuade him to fly to the US to attend the Atlanta Games. Plans included watching the final of the coxless pairs rowing, featuring Matthew Pinsent and Steve Redgrave, which delivered Britainaposs only gold medal at the Games. But cricket fan Mr Major pulled out of a three-night trip to America at the end of July, despite months of organisation behind the scenes, amid concerns from aides he would go to Englandaposs match with Pakistan. Downing Street private secretary Rachael Reynolds wrote to the PM saying: I understand that you are thinking of staying here for the Lordaposs Test in preference to going to the Olympics. “While having to declare certain personal interest here ... I do think it would be a pityyou were to give up going entirely.”  . Heathrow nearly had its name changed to pay tribute to Winston Churchill John Major considered renaming Heathrow Airport after Sir Winston Churchill. The then Prime Minister believed the idea of making Britain’s biggest airport a memorial to the Second World War leader was “intriguing”. The Tory leader asked senior Whitehall aides to explore the proposal after London businessman Harvey Spack suggested Sir Winston Churchill Airport was better than “stupid” Heathrow. The premieraposs reply to Mr Spack said: “Thank you for your letter of  September and for your intriguing idea about renaming Heathrow airport after Sir Winston Churchill. “I am looking into this, and I am grateful to you for raising it.”

title: remain leave chiefs unite call
story: NewsRemain and Leave chiefs unite to call on Britain to come together for Brexit chief Matthew Elliott and Remain boss Will Straw called on the nation to finally begin the healing process as Britain marches into a new decadeShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  JAN NewsVote Leave chief Matthew Elliott " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrexit rivals, civic leaders and religious figureheads today urge Britain to reunite and reconnect as the country marches into a new decade. As the UK prepares to leave the European Union in just  days, the Leave and Remain campaign chiefs call on the nation to finally begin the healing process – a plea echoed by the Archbishop of Canterbury in his New Year message. Three-and-a-half years since voters split by % to % to quit the EU, Matthew Elliott and Will Straw urge Britain to “leave behind a decade of ision and begin our decade of reconnection”. Mr Elliott was chief executive of Vote Leave, the official pro-Brexit campaign, while Mr Straw was his direct counterpart as executive director of Britain Stronger in Europe. They hope factions, friends and families separated by the passionate arguments surrounding the EU debate can now put aside their dferences. The identical demands spanning the political ide are aimed at moving on from the bitter isions which erupted in the run-up to the  referendum and which are yet to be bridged. Their message comes in an open letter signed by a cross-section of society leaders to mark the start of a new decade. Signatories include GMB union chief Tim Roache Confederation of British Industry director Dame Carolyn Fairbairn and Glastonbury Festival organiser Emily Eavis.  Faith chiefs, think tank bosses and British Olympic Association chairman Sir Hugh Robertson have also added their names. The letter says: “As we start this new year and new decade, our country feels more fragmented than any of us would like. “Too often we hear that our isions – by class or geography, by politics, age, race or by faith – have come to define us. “If we are not happy with the state of our society, it falls to us all to do something about it. “New Year is the time for resolutions and on this first day of the s, we urge others to join us in making a resolution for the new decade. “Our resolution is to reconnect. “To reach out to just one person we don’t know, or from whom we have drted apart. “To start rebuilding connections between neighbours and fellow citizens. “While our politics and media have become more polarised we, as people, have not.”Britain is still to recover from the rancour unleashed in the run-up to the landmark referendum.Just a week before polling day, Labour MP Jo Cox was murdered in her West Yorkshire constituency by a far-right extremist shouting: “Britain first!” Experts have blamed the Brexit debate for driving a rise in hate offences ever since.Racist or religious abuse incidents recorded by police in England and Wales jumped % in the month after the UK voted to quit the EU. Some , such crimes were logged in July , rising to , in July , according to the Home Office. Figures revealed in October last year showed an % year-on-year rise in race hate crimes recorded by officers. There were , offences in -, according to Home Office statistics. That compared with , in -, which included the referendum and subsequent months. Charities claimed the figures were the tip of the iceberg because many offences go unreported. The Home Office admitted at the time there had been short-term genuine rises in hate crime following certain events such as the Brexit referendum. In the aftermath of the EU vote, the National Police Chiefsapos Council revealed hate crimes reported to police soared % between polling day and the following Sunday, compared with the equivalent days four weeks earlier. The letter published today is the latest attempt to urge people to “find some common ground”. It goes on: There is much that we share with each other: sit any two people down together and they will find some common ground. “So the power of reconnection will depend on how many of us, as citizens, step up together. “Every institution, too – not just government but education, business, sport, civic society and faith – should play its part in helping bridge social ides. “Today is about a small first step that we can all take – to leave behind a decade of ision and begin our decade of reconnection.”  In his traditional New Year message, the Church of Englandaposs most senior minister, Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby, also pleads for chasms to be overcome and the UK to start healing isions. Archbishop Justin says he has been inspired by the heroism and hope of RNLI volunteers at Dover leboat station. In his message, broadcast on BBC at pm today, he says: As we wonder how we are going to start healing some of the isions that weaposve seen over recent years, the sort of people at this leboat station are signs of hope. Iaposve met some of the over  volunteers who are involved in keeping this station operational  hours a day,  days a year. “Itaposs not just a group of people working together, itaposs a family. The seagoing crew includes a student, a train driver, a chef, an electrician. The youngest is , the oldest is . When their pagers go off - day or night - theyaposre prepared to risk everything to rescue whoever needs their help. There are so many ways we can connect with others. “It could be by joining a voluntary organisation or a charity, it may be sorting food in a foodbank or joining a leboat crew. When we hear someone described as a Good Samaritan, we think about that person taking the time to help another. “But itaposs a story told by Jesus about someone taking the risk of reaching out to another who was very dferent to them. “Yes, the person needed help - but they also needed connection.”

title: voice mirror after divisive decade
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: After isive decade its time for the Tremendous TwentiesIn the past decade, there were plenty of moments which have cast a terrible stain on this country’s history. As we look ahead, we vow to fight back against those that seek to ide us. For togetherness is the superpower we possess...ShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  DEC Updated:,  JAN NewsopinionPro-Brexit protesters rally opposite Parliament as The Chancellor of The Exchequer Philip Hammond delivers the Autumn Statement " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailToday we enter a new decade. A new beginning. A new chance to get things right. And by goodness we need it. There were many great moments in the past decade – the London Olympics, two royal weddings and Nessa finally proposing to Smithy. But there were plenty more moments from which we can take no pride at all. Moments which have cast a terrible stain on this country’s history. The greed of underregulated bankers coupled with an ideological policy of austerity led to a decade of misery for many. Foodbanks, practically unheard of  years ago, popped up in almost every town and city. Rough sleepers lined our streets. Waiting lists for our brilliant but beleaguered NHS grew longer. The cult of inidualism took hold, crushing beneath it our nation’s greatest attributes: moderation, politeness and “agreeing to disagree”. Instead we disagreed on anything – and everything. RIPPED Brexit hammered a stake through our nation’s soul which the extremists, the know-it-alls and the downright evil pushed and pulled until we were ripped entirely in two. Technological change whirred so fast that promised winds of change became a destructive tornado. Billion dollar social media firms peddled fake news, meddled in elections and shared “how to” suicide guides for our kids. Amazon ravaged our high streets and sneered at our tax system. Smartphones intended to connect us only isolated us. We slipped into a loneliness crisis and mental health catastrophe. And so austerity, inidualism and technology allied themselves to fracture our communities and leave us adrt in a perfect storm of sadness. Hundreds of thousands of shops, libraries, pubs, youth clubs, bus services and bingo halls closed. The glue which holds this nation together dried up and flaked off. And all that time we continued to overheat, overuse and undervalue the planet on which we live. And yet. There is hope. There is always hope. For we are a country which has taken on greater challenges than those we face today – and survived. Looking around over the past few festive weeks we have all been reminded how the British sense of family, togetherness and having a laugh come what may, remains a potent force. And now, in this new decade, we must use this togetherness as the weapon with which we fight back. As Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby says tomorrow we must start healing the isions we’ve seen over recent years.  The Daily Mirror has been the Heart of Britain for  years. We are the voice of the millions of compassionate, decent, hard-working people who are the backbone of this nation. DEBATE We speak to and for readers on both sides of the Brexit debate, young and old, from the North and the South, in big cities and small towns. And this year we – readers and writers together – will do our bit to fight back against those who would ide us. We will step up our brilliant Britain Talks project which brings together people with dfering views over a cup of tea to find common ground. We will relentlessly battle against social media companies, online giants and gig economy employers who know the price of everything, but the value of nothing.  We will hold our politicians to account for the language they use and the promises they make. We will again throw open the doors of the Mirror newsroom to young people to report the news. But we’ll never ever take for granted our loyal, more senior readers. We will every day tell stories of how the indomitable British spirit has achieved great things, just as we do at the Mirror’s uplting Pride of Britain Awards.

title: ian lavery communities represented labour
story: NewsopinionIan Lavery: Communities represented by Labour for generations felt abandoned this yearDivided parties can’t win. Let’s get back to debating in a forthright but respectful way, remembering what we have in common and stop reinforcing press attacks on our own partyShareCommentsByIan Lavery:,  DEC NewsopinionMP Ian Lavery shared his opinion with Daily Mirror " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - politicsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email It is said ‘history is written by the victors’ but in Labour’s leadership contest, it seems the architects of our defeat are attempting to steal the pen.To survive, we must understand why we lost and articulate a bold vision for the future. It seems ridiculous to point out it was not our policies that led to defeat.For some, that would be a neat conclusion allowing them toto a bland centrism of . But it isn’t true. Labour lost because of our Brexit position, infighting, a collapse of industry in our communities and a lack of trust in our ability to deliver.Talk of a second referendum was seen by many as a way to foist Remain upon them. Communities represented by Labour for generations felt abandoned. It is time to outline a positive vision of the future outside of the EU. Divided parties can’t win. Let’s get back to debating in a forthright but respectful way, remembering what we have in common and stop reinforcing press attacks on our own party. Industries around which many of our communities were built have gone.

story: NewsopinionIf someone has to tell you that its "just a normal argument", the chances are it probably isntDomestic abuse spikes at Christmas and most victims refuse to believe it is happening to them. But itaposs more likely the festive season makes you extra-vigilant. Keeping an eye on how much they drink. Worrying what your loved ones will notice. Hiding the cost of things. Terried that now thereaposs witnesses.  Victims of domestic abuse are usually the last ones to realise it. You will probably tell people,it comes up, that someone who stays with their abuser is an idiot. You genuinely believe this, because you do not know much about it. Whether you are having your money taken, your liberty restricted, or your peace of mind destroyed, you are far too close to see it properly. You canapost get perspectiveyouaposre not at peace. Calls to police about domestic incidents spike at Christmas. The combination of alcohol, financial and family pressure, and being in close quarters adds to the pressure which you have got used to dealing with - like a temperamental, dysal cooker that will burn the roast,you donapost know the trick of how to close the door just so. You might think that knowing such tricks, spotting the problems early and moving quickly to deflect them, makes you a great chef. Actually what it means is youaposve got a knackered cooker.  A victim calls the police every  seconds for help. According to the Office of National Statistics, last year there were .m domestic abuse incidents and crimes recorded by police. Only  in every  such reports ever leads to an arrest. And the first time somebody asks for help is, on average, the th time something that is not normal has happened to them.They will not get effective help until it has happened  times.On average, victims live with their abuser for  or  years before they leave. Some for decades. Two thirds of them will try to leave  or  times in the year before they finally manage it. But not you. Because youaposve got this.  You are strong. You know how to fix it, and what sets it off. You know not to wear those clothes, not to talk about those things, not to ask that question. You know when to send the kids to your mumaposs, when to say sorry, when to go limp because thataposs the quickest way to make it end.You know itaposs normal to argue. You know itaposs normal for things to get a bit out of hand. Itaposs normal that someone with problems - perhaps drugs, or booze, issues at work or in their past - needs you to understand them better. They need YOUR help.Maybe the first time you said sorry it felt wrong, but it was the only way to make things calm again. Maybe you now think that youaposre always the one to blame. But you are strong, so you stay. Even though it is not normal to have to convince yourself to do that. It is not normal for blood to be spilled on bedsheets. Itaposs not normal for the neighbours to be so alarmed they call the police. Itaposs not a normal argument,you are down by one bedside lamp at the end of it and someoneaposs had to go to AE to get patched up. It IS entirely normal for the person responsible to tell you that itaposs fine, that you made them do it, thatonly you donapost do that again they wonapost get so angry, that you need to apologise to them and thataposs the only way to make up. It is normal for them to want, and expect, and need all the sympathy thataposs going.And itaposs entirely normal that you believe them. They use the same words and phrases our parents use, likeyou do that again... They play on the fact you love them. They tell you they love you, or perhaps theyaposve stopped telling you that, because it makes you work harder to hear it. It is normal that you bend. It is not normal that you break your spine doing it.  When was the last time you did not worry about what would happen at Christmas  When was the last time you worked, went out, had fun, flirted, relaxed, or laughed like you used to  When was the last time you talked about your relationship to someone , and didnapost lie about it  It is not normal to worry what the person who is supposed to love you will do next. It is not normal to hide the truth, wear clothes that cover it up, or pray the family donapost notice how afraid you are. You are right. Someone who can put up with all of this is very strong, and capable of deep and abiding love. It is the person doing it to you who is weak.  They are the one who feels something in their le is out of control - anything, from their age to their job to an addiction. Perhaps thereaposs an unexpected pregnancy, or a bereavement. But one way or another, they havenapost quite got a grip on things. So they hold on to you a bit tighter. At the start itaposs just a hug. But over time, you find it harder to breathe, to be you. You change, bend, accommodate, compromise, and every time you do they ask for more. Itaposs never enough. Something will always make them cross again, and you have to bend further. If youaposre lucky it will stop all by itself. Butitaposs not fixed itaposll come back. Last December Becky Dell was inspired by the David Attenborough show Blue Planet to do her bit to help the environment. The Londoner decided to only buy food, drink and basic toiletries in . Writing on Twitter Becky said she watched, with shame plastic floating in the oceans and wondered how much was hers. So, aside from mascara and moisturiser, Becky did not buy anything she didnapost need. That meant no clothes, shoes, presents, other makeup, hair products, jewellery, bags, decorations, anything disposable, plants, flowers, house items etc. And the money that she saved from not splashing out would be given to a selection of charities and grassroots organisations. Becky says she ended up saving and donating £,.. But there were times when emergencies meant she had to buy something. On Twitter she said: I bought  things during the year, for example, a new jacket when my zip broke at - up a mountain, brr, a couple of essential things for my very elderly cats and a couple of essential house items. Each one made me really annoyed! And friends and family understood her challenge and supported Beckyaposs decision, with the thrty musical director making presents herself instead. And there were some things she really missed. Becky wrote: The thing I missed the most was buying plants and flowers, I love nature and found that hard. Solutions were growing flowers from seedand getting cuttings from friends . I now have rhubarb growing!!  At first, she said, it was quite easy: January to August was surprisingly easybut it got WAY hard from August, as clothes started running out and however much I darned my socks they just stayed holey. It got easier in December as I could start counting down. After  months of austere living the first thing Becky plans on splashing out on is socks, plants, some nice tea towels and a tea strainer.

Those with long memories may remember Baba foretold that Putin and Trumpaposs lives would be in danger last year, suggesting some kind of cosmic rollover.  Another recurrent theme in her predictions has been the destruction of Asia. Baba foresaw that “a big wave will cover the shore and people will disappear underwater” in what some interpreted as the destruction of Thailand by a huge tsunami in . The outlook in  is equally as bleak, with more tsunamis and earthquakes scheduled to hit the continent. A meteorite is also predicted to fall on Russia.  Perhaps the most ominous prediction of the clairvoyant was that the European continent could reach the end of its existence at the hands of Muslim extremists The Bulgarian suggested that extremists would use an arsenal of chemical weapons against Europeans”. Supporters of Baba are keen to emphasise how spot on she has been, with % accurate a phrase that regularly crops up in fan forums. According to baba-vanga, the figure is drawn from research conducted by Professor Georgi Lozanov - a former director of the Bulgarian Institute of Suggestology. The nuclear war pencilled in for the years  to  also failed to materialise. Perhaps more damning is the seemingly non-existent nature of her prophecies. Confetti filled Times Square as couples kissed and crowds screamed with joy as the decade came to an end. Dubai has also welcomed  with pyrotechnics, fireworks, lasers and wingsuit flyers. The cash-rich United Arab Emirates city has splashed out after a million people descended on Downtown. Celebrations have reached Europe as Moscow rings in  with fireworks in the Red Square at pm UK time. Russian President Vladimir Putin has given his address to the nation on New Year’s and.. it’s quite something. In it he speaks of “our ancestors – the heroic, unyielding generation of victors” and congratulates “everyone who went through the most dficult trials for the sake of us and for the future of our country. I bow low before you.” He ends by saying “Friends, the New Year is already knocking at the door. Let’s wish each other and our Motherland peace and prosperity.” London Mayor Sadiq Khan promised the “best fireworks London has ever seen” to ring in the new decade. Mr Khan said the capital would “project confidence” on the world stage through an impressive display at the New Year’s Eve celebrations. Speaking in the city centre ahead of the celebrations, Mr Khan told the PA news agency: “Hand on heart, these are going to be the best fireworks London has ever seen.” He added the “world” was watching the display and he hoped it would show London was a “global city”. Hong Kong welcomed  with neon-lit promenades - despite more massive rallies by protesters. Authorities there cancelled the main midnight fireworks display for the first time in a decade, citing security concerns. A Symphony of Lights took place instead, involving projections on the cityaposs tallest skyscrapers, while smaller-scale pyrotechnics were launched from waterfront rooftops. Spectacular firework displays have been enjoyed where though, including in Bangkok, Kuala Lumpur, Jakarta and across both Koreas. In Indonesia, while fireworks erupted over Garuda Wisnu Kencana cultural park in Bali, torrential rains threatened to make the celebrations a wash out in the capital of Jakarta. But tens of thousands of revellers ploughed on. The island volcano of Anak Krakatau erupted earlier today, just as it did last year just before Christmas day, triggering a tsunami which killed hundreds of people. This dampened New Year events along Indonesia’s coastal areas near the Sunda Strait today. As in Hong Kong, thousands of Indians also planned to greet the new year with protests. They are angered by a citizenship law that they say will discriminate against Muslims and chip away at India’s secular constitution. Demonstrations were planned in New Delhi, in the grip of its second coldest winter in more than a century, as well as Mumbai and other cities. Nevertheless, the new year Jasn a Bhopal  in Bhopal India went off without a hitch. And Sydney welcomed  with a dazzling fireworks display as Australiaaposs New Yearaposs Eve celebrations took on a sombre tone amid the most devastating bush fire crisis ever.    More than a dozen people have been killed and towns have been ravaged as wildfires rage across much of the country. Sydneyaposs harbourfront was cloaked in smoke as hundreds of thousands of revellers gathered to watch a -minute fireworks show that went ahead despite calls for it to be scrapped. More than , people had signed an online petition urging the city to cancel the display out of respect and donate the money to the firefighting effort. High fire danger and extreme temperatures - western Sydney hit C on Tuesday - had led to the cancellation of several planned New Yearaposs fireworks displays, including in the national capital Canberra. But Sydney pressed ahead with its plans and was granted a fire ban exemption, while other cities had their applications rejected. Earlier on Tuesday, Sydney’s Lord Mayor Clover Moore defended the decision and delivered a scathing attack on the national government’s climate change record.  Scientists have said climate change is fuelling a longer and more intense bush fire season this summer. The mayor told reporters that much of the New Yearaposs event’s budget had already been spent and the celebration generates almost £million for the New South Wales economy. Signs set up around the harbour told people how to donate money to help those affected by fires. Bush fires are raging amid a drought and summer heatwave that has sent temperatures soaring above C in all of Australiaaposs states. The crisis worsened on Tuesday as two more people died, five others were missing and feared dead, and thousands were forced to flee to beaches in a wall of smoke under a blood-red sky to escape. Police said a father and son died in the early hours of Tuesday defending their home in Cobargo, near the coast in the state of New South Wales ,  miles south of Sydney. The town was hit by one out-of-control fire which roared into the community in the middle of the night, with its main street bearing the impact. Further south, fires continued to blaze out of control in the state of Victoria, where some , people were forced to take shelter on the beach in the holiday town of Mallacoota, in the East Gippsland district along the Pacic coast. Around , more people were sheltering in community centres in the town. Those sheltering on the beach were advised to go into the waterthe fire situation worsened. Similar advice was given to people in several NSW coastal towns, where fearful residents and holidaymakers had also abandoned their dwellings to move onto beaches. People in Mallacoota posted on social media about hearing the roar of the fire, circulating photos showing how, in the words of some, the smoke had turned the day into night. As defence force personnel assisted firefighters and volunteers in tackling some of the worst blazes, eight fires were burning at emergency level across NSW, with a similar number ongoing in Victoria, and two more in the island state of Tasmania.

title: derby shows we shouldnt be so far behind utd
story: Dundee boss James McPake says his side’s second-half performance at Tannadice on Friday shows there shouldn’t be a dference of  points between the teams.The Dark Blues made the very short trip to face rivals Dundee United on the back of two dispiriting derby defeats already this season.Since the last one, a - loss at home, the Tangerines have raced away at the top of the Championship, leaving Dundee trailing them by  points after nine wins on the spin.However, this time James was disappointed not to come away with three points after a strong second-half display that, he insists, shows why the Dark Blues are frustrated to be so far behind.Dundee United - Dundee: Dorrans# first goal earns Dee derby point" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united---dundee-dorrans-first-goal-earns-dee-derby-point embed # secretDkByqtiVf" data-secret"DkByqtiVf" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"He said: “Real credit to Dundee United. I’m not coming here and saying this or that.“They are  points clear of us in the league, deservedly so, so they are doing a lot right.“They are the ones at the top of the league so credit to them but we showed why we should be so disappointed that we are so far behind.“There is a real belief we should have come away with three points.“Performance-wise, it was night and day from what we have given in previous derbies.“But it is the result that is the important thing and we are disappointed that we never got all three points.“It was important to show to our fans that we can turn up and dig in when we need to.“I thought some of the stuff we played was brilliant. In the second half, I thought we were excellent.“Graham Dorrans and Fin Robertson controlled everything that happened in the game.“Disappointment is the over-riding emotion probably but I might look back over it and say: ‘You know what, a point after going behind so early is good.’“But there is just real disappointment over how superior we were in the second half but we have not got the win.”After Nicky Clark had put United in front after just five minutes, the away side came back into the contest after the break with Dorrans smashing in a low volley shortly after the restart to open his scoring account for the club.James added: “It was a lovely goal.“He has getting himself into positions where keepers are pulling off world-class saves.“He is getting close to full fitness. His body is good and he plays  minutes.“You are seeing a bit of dig, as well. There is no fear there from someone who has had two years out with a knee injury.“I know exactly what has gone on with his knee and ankle because I have been so close to him.“Seeing him flying into tackles, you are pleased that there is no holding back and that he’s walking away from it.“Listen, Graham Dorrans is too good for this league. That is why we are delighted to have him.”The Dens gaffer is also delighted to have Dorrans around to help with the development of -year-old Robertson after the youngster put in an accomplished display in his first-ever Dundee derby.“It has been a bit of a learning experience for Fin to have both Graham and Paul McGowan in the same midfield as him,” added James.“Looking back, I probably shouldn’t have left him out of the previous derby at Tannadice.“I’ve been advised not to say it because maybe you are doubting yourself but, looking back, I shouldn’t have done it because he has proved how consistent he can be. Big games don’t faze him.“I put him out there because he is one of my better players and deserves it.“He needs help but he is getting it.”

title: national organisation thanks dundee mum for breast milk donation after seeing tele story
story: A national organisation has thanked a young Dundee mum for donating breast milk, after seeing an article on the Tele website.Shelby O#Shea decided to give back to Dundee#s Ninewells Hospital bank.#The Scotland-wide donor milk bank service was officially launched in June .It benefits more than  of the most vulnerable babies a year, allowing them to be fed breastmilk for a longer period of title: impressive four months at pj live and 2020 to be amazing
story: The new PJ Live is already a huge success, despite only being open for four months.New figures show , visitors have attended the events complex since it opened, with , tickets sold to  arena shows,  conferences,  banquets and  exhibitions.At a total cost of £ million, the building was delivered by Aberdeen City Council in partnership with Henry Boot Developments to replace the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre.It appears to be worth the investment already, with a successful future in sight.Samantha Todd, senior marketing executive at PJ Live, said: “It’s very impressive. It’s been an amazing first four months. We couldn’t be prouder of the team or how the venue has gone, really.“We had some big events. We started with Offshore Europe and we had two extraordinary nights of Michael Buble, and of course BBC Sports Personality of the Year broadcast across the UK.”The recent awards show, which celebrates the best in sport, crowned England cricketer Ben Stokes as winner.Presenters Gary Lineker, Clare Balding and Gabby Logan, took to the stage for the highly-anticipated event in front of a crowd of , people.The complex, which is the largest of its kind in the north of Scotland, attracts visitors from across the country and beyond.Samantha said: “It’s a brand new state-of-the-art building so we’ve got an arena that can hold , people standing.“It’s the largest standing arena in Scotland.“We broke that record with a sold-out crowd for Gerry Cinnamon with , people.”The venue boasts world-class conference and exhibition facilities which are all sustainably powered by local, renewable energy sources.The development also comprises two on-site hotels including the adjoining four-star Hilton with  bedrooms, the Aloft Hotel with  bedrooms, and a third budget hotel to be confirmed with a further  bedrooms.It is part of the city’s aim to invest and grow in other areas beyond the oil and gas industry.While Edinburgh and Glasgow are often touted as being the go-to cities for events in Scotland, the arrival of PJ Live is expected to bring in a surge of visitors throughout the year.Samantha said: “Events in Scotland are changing and Aberdeen is at the forefront of it all.“We’ve got this state-of-the-art venue and we’re accessible by plane, trains, cars – everything.”A range of high-profile artists and acts are due to perform at the events complex next year, with a large number of shows already sold-out.She added: “We’ve got Lewis Capaldi in March, which has sold out. We’ve got Cirque du Soleil, Stereophonics, the  and Simple Minds.“There’s really exciting performances coming to Aberdeen for  and a lot more to come.”It is expected that the current statistics will be given a boost over the next year.Samantha said: “I think it’s a really great representation of what’s yet to come for .“It’s going to be an amazing year for PJ Live but Aberdeen as well.”

title: poundland submits plans aberdeen shopping centre store
story: A discount retailer is making plans to open in a former book shop on the city’s Union Street, The Evening Express can reveal.Poundland has applied for a building warrant from Aberdeen City Council to spend around £, on an internal fit-out of the former Waterstones retail store in the Trinity Centre.The prime city centre site has been lying vacant since the national bookseller moved from the store in May .Dustin Macdonald, chairman of the City Centre Community Council, said he was pleased to see the large unit occupied again.He said: “It’s good to see there’s still interest in Union Street property.“That shop has sat empty for a while and filling such a big unit can’t have been easy.”However, councillor Bill Cormie, who represents Rosemount, said: “We need to watch that Union Street doesn’t become a long mall of bookies and discount retailers.”The works would also include the installation of new stairs at ground to first floor level.Waterstones signed a -year lease in  for a two-storey unit in the Bon Accord Centre, Aberdeen.The Trinity Centre branch of the bookstore, which had long been a feature of Union Street, was previously occupied by another book store, Ottakar’s.Speaking at the time, bookshop manager Iain Dench said the Bon Accord Centre plan offered an “exciting prospect” for the business.Poundland has a store at  Union Street but it is not known whether this will be affected by the plan.The retailer also has shops in Berryden Retail Park, Inverurie and Elgin.The Trinity Centre and Poundland could not be reached for comment.

title: room-inn-sandys-tontine-triumph
story: A PEEBLES historian has gone upmarket in her quest to discover the Royal Burghs past.Sandy Whitnell has previously researched and documented the depravity suffered in the town at the Peebles Poorhouse.From the late s the Combination Poorhouse on Rosetta Road was home to many down-on-their-luck locals.In a bid to find some balance, Sandy went from rags to riches with her next project - and has now charted the history of the glamorous Tontine Hotel.From her initial , word essay for a local history meeting, she decided to investigate the High Street hostelry even further.And this month The Public Rooms of the County has been published.The -page booklet provides readers with a remarkable journey from the hotels grand opening in  all the way through to its popular place on todays High Street.Sandy told us: "It was after Id done my talk on the Peebles poorhouse that I wanted to go to the other extreme and see where the wealthy were staying at the time."It seemed such a shame that the history of The Tontine Hotel hadnt been done before, so I initially wrote up , words."That was just the start."There were three prominent figures involved in the creation of the Tontine Hotel - local MP Sir John Montgomery, banker John Hay, and army captain Robert Nutler Campbell.Their aspirations for a prominent high-class hotel in Peebles led to  people purchasing shares to fund the project.Tontine, named after Italian economist Tonti, derives from the type of investment plan used.The Tontine was built at a cost of pound, - around pound, in todays money - and the doors were opened in .From its early days The Tontine was a popular meeting place for many organisations and societies in and around Peebles.It was also a busy destination for travellers arriving by coach and horse, with its stables being well used, in the days before the railway reached the town.And it wasnt just horses who were stabled at the Tontine, with reports from  of an elephant from Battys Travelling Menagerie dying while being kept at the Tontine.The Public Rooms of the County highlights the grandeur offered with the magnicent ballroom regarded as its crowning glory.Sandays enjoyable book also introduces readers to the vast array of characters who managed the hotel - from Frenchman Benoit Lenoir at the height of the Napoleonic wars and entrepreneurial James Cameron to the bullish Thomas Noble and heroic Duncan McPherson - until its sale into private ownership in the s.The purchase by William Borthwick and Duncan McPherson ended the Tontine arrangement, but the premises kept the name.Although the hotel was sold to a national chain in , it ed to private ownership more recently with the current proprietors Kate and Gordon Innes.Author Sandy admits she struck gold during her research with an enquiry at the National Records office in Edinburgh.She added: "The officer at the National Records produced three unopened boxes full of original documents relating to the hotel."It was an absolute treasure trove for any historian and has helped me produce a very detailed history of this much-loved hotel."The Public Rooms of the County, priced at pound, is available from The Tontine Hotel as well as Amazon.All profits from the sale of The Public Rooms of the County will be shared between the Peebles Foodbank and the Peebles Community Talking Books project.

title: happiness-borders-comes-dalai-lamas-blessing
story: THE Dalai Lama has given his blessing to a new course being run in the Borders which promises to make people happier and the world a better place.The eight-week course is designed by the Action for Happiness organisation - a UK based movement with over , members which takes action for a happier world.Entitled Exploring What Matters, the weekly courses will be offered in Peebles and Innerleithen in the New Year.It is a secular project based on science rather than faith and is open to people of all backgrounds.The course is backed by the Dalai Lama, who said: ldquoAs patron of Action for Happiness I am delighted to see the work being done by members of this movement to create a happier and more caring society."I wholeheartedly support the Exploring What Matters course and hope that many thousands of people will benefit from it and be inspired to take their own action to help create a happier world.Analysis of the course has found that it leaves people both happier and more pro-social, with participants reporting increases in levels of le satisfaction, mental wellbeing, compassion and social trust.Many say the course is le-changing.In Exploring What Matters, local groups meet for eight weeks, with each session exploring a big question.They start with "What really matters in le " and then "What really makes us happy ".These are followed by sessions on dealing with adversity, having good relationships, caring for others, and creating happier workplaces and communities.They end with "How can we create a happier world The first eight week course is being run in Peebles on a voluntary basis by Suzi Gibson and Laura Swan in Space, Greenside every Thursday starting on January .Suzi said: ldquoIrsquom very excited to be running this course because happier iniduals make for a happier community and I am passionate about bringing people together to discuss what matters. I canrsquot think of a better use of my time than helping myself and others be happier.The Innerleithen-based course is being run by Lois Hindley and Cath Shepheard and takes place at Innerleithen Church of Scotland every Wednesday starting on January .And whatrsquos even better is the cost of happiness is free, but the organisers do ask for a small donation to cover costs.If you would like to search for happiness contact Laura Swan at hello@lauraswan

title: eleanor-nears-100k-target-fundraising-coffee-morning
story: AN -year-old Borders woman has raised more than pound, for a cancer charity.Eleanor Moffat began fundraising following the death of her younger sister through breast cancer.And her latest coffee morning last month in her hometown of Coldstream boosted her personal fundraising tally by another pound.Eleanor, who hopes to raise an incredible pound, for Breast Cancer Now, regularly hosts coffee mornings, charity dinners and bingo nights.She said: "Itrsquos wonderful that so many people came to my coffee morning in support of Breast Cancer Now.ldquoIrsquom absolutely delighted to have raised over pound from the event, brining me even closer to my goal of reaching pound, for a cause that is so close to my heart."Thank you to everyone who continues to give so generously.Since Eleanor began fundraising for Breast Cancer Now in  she has raised pound,..Kirsty Potter, fundraising manager at Breast Cancer Now, added: "Breast cancer is the most common cancer in the UK ndash around , people are diagnosed with breast cancer and around , people die from the disease each year in Scotland."We must act now to make greater progress for everyone affected by this disease.ldquoWe are very grateful to every one of our amazing community fundraisers who help us to fund vital breast cancer research and support."We are delighted that Eleanorrsquos coffee morning was a big success and on behalf of Breast Cancer Now I would like to sincerely thank Eleanor and the local community in Coldstream for continuing to support our work, which provides support for today and hope for the future for everyone affected by breast cancer.
